body: In any case, my suspicion is that the delivery got stopped because the few consumers that got many unacked messages and the negative counts might be a consequence of that. I'm not really sure, I'll check the code tomorrow to refresh the logic there.

> Have this problem happened multiple times or just one occourrence?

This has happened several times

> Does disconnecting/reconnecting a single consumer unblock that consumer?

Haven't tried disconnecting a single consumer, have tried introducing new consumers but won't work.

> Does disconnecting/reconnecting all the consumers "resolves" the issue?

I believe so, couldn't try that yesterday cause we had some other troubles.

> The limit kicked in for the subscription.

The strange thing is that we have `ackTimeout` of 30 seconds and that consumer had been for over a day mostly receiving no messages. I should be impossible for the consumer to be blocked for such a long time when after aproximately 30 seconds those messages should be redelivered.

> In any case, my suspicion is that the delivery got stopped because the few consumers that got many unacked messages and the negative counts might be a consequence of that. I'm not really sure, I'll check the code tomorrow to refresh the logic there.

Probably, don't really know why unacked messages has a negative count. What I can say is that we typically have LOTS of redeliveries. As before, even though some consumers received a lot o messages and got blocked, even if most messages were not acked, 30seconds later the consumer should unblock because it should ask for a redelivery.

Maybe it would be possible to reproduce in a test env by setting a very low ack-timeout (eg: 1 sec) and have the consumers to randomly exceed the threshold to excersise that code path.

> I think it's useful to let the user control that. We should perform some validation to ensure the values are correct and reasonable.

But how can we validate `bookkeeperEnsemble/Quorum` dynamically, because this information is stored in zk and suppose to be accessed by BK-Client. ?

> If we always read from the config object we should be good.

Yes, that we can do to avoid topic unloading.

> But how can we validate bookkeeperEnsemble/Quorum dynamically, because this information is stored in zk and suppose to be accessed by BK-Client. ?

The info is stored with the namespace policies and passed to ManagedLedger when the topic is loaded.

> The info is stored with the namespace policies and passed to ManagedLedger when the topic is loaded.

No, I mean, against which value we can do validation.? eg. pulsar cluster just have 3 bookie nodes and user is not aware about it and user tries to set-persistence policies `bookkeeperEnsemble=5, bookkeeperWriteQuorum=5`.  So, in that case we have to validate persistence policy when user try to set it but then how would broker know valid value for `bookkeeperEnsemble or Write/Read-Quorum`.

> No, I mean, against which value we can do validation.?  

I mean, we can have set max configured at the broker level for the number of replicas and ensemble size. Same for mark-delete rate.

Also, we need to validate that `e >= w >= a >= 1`
`pulsar-broker` build time increased from 22 mins to 24 mins. so, I think not a big difference.

Ok, I think I have a rough idea of what is happening. 

The issue is triggered when the ack-timeout is triggered, the message is re-sent to a different consumer and then the original consumer is acking the message. 

I think we're decreasing the unacked count even though the message was not in the set anymore for consumer 1. I'll get a fix shortly

Mostly readability, there is no need to use updater trick to get value of a
volatile variable

In future, if we want to send additional information in metadata then we have to encode multiple properties into metadata-string. So, instead `string metadata`, what if we add  `KeyValue properties` ? I think that can address sending multiple properties in metadata?
I agree to have optional arbitrary options. Regarding the version, is that general enough to have a "version" field?

@rdhabalia The value has to be byte array for efficiency. Instead of creating another type, its better to keep it this way.

@merlimat When application implements metadata, it could contain more than version. One other example could be information about the AES key or if key is managed using kms, it could be the detailed information about the key. So, I thought keeping a generic name "metadata" could address various use cases.

> The value has to be byte array for efficiency. Instead of creating another type, its better to keep it this way.

Actually, I was pointing to `metadata` type as `KeyValue(existing string key-value type)`. We don't have to change `value` field and we can keep it as `bytes` only. 
If we introduce field-name as `version` then I think `string` type is enough because we know it will contain only version. But if we want to use it for multiple fields in future then it will be hard to accommodate in one string type. 
So, may be we can call it as `version` right now, and in future introduce `properties` if require?
Thats a good point. We could add it as key/value pair. I'll update the pull request.
Pushed this change as well

> If we can break compatibility with the existing version, I think we should make data in Message class return bytes type like getMessage of Java Client.

I think that as well.. Using `message.data()` to return bytes seems a better option: 

 * In Python 2.7, there should be no difference between `bytes` and `string` as I understand
 * In Python 3.x, it's actually very tricky to return a proper string from the API, since we don't know the eventual string encoding, if it is a string a all. 
 * By always returning `bytes` we force the user to deal and reason about the encoding, and it will be the same as in C++ and Java (C++ string can actually hold whatever content). 

@kyontan Thanks for finding this out and the change looks good, can you also update the `pulsar.py` wrapper documentation to specify that the return type will be `bytes`? https://github.com/apache/incubator-pulsar/blob/df5be460bf1bf4f04c5572452aafd879cd1213f6/pulsar-client-cpp/python/pulsar.py#L140
Also, please add a test to verify the object returned by `data()` method is of type `bytes` after the change, so that we can prevent future changes from breaking this.
